entry.title: AWS S3 and SAP PaPM Cloud Inbound Integration
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community!

I’m excited to share a hands-on experience that might just come in handy if you are trying to consume data from AWS S3 to SAP PaPM Cloud. If you’re familiar with the excellent blog on integrating Azure Blob Storage with SAP PaPM Cloud, the setup feels similar but with an AWS twist.

Just like in the Azure Blob Storage integration, you’ll work across three core applications:

  1. AWS S3: This is your source system where the raw data is stored
  2. SAP HANA Cloud: This acts as a bridge between AWS S3 and SAP PaPM Cloud to secure connectivity and persistence
  3. SAP PaPM Cloud (Standard Model or Universal Model): This is the destination of your raw data which you will used for your business model and calculations

Also, before working on the integration, make sure to meet the following prerequisites:

  • An AWS account and IAM user with an access to the S3 bucket
  • Get the Access Key and Secret Key for the IAM User
  • Modeling rights in SAP PaPM Cloud

 

Let's get started!

Note: The screenshot in this blog is for illustration purposes only.

Procedure:

We will begin the setup by logging to the Amazon Web Service (AWS).

AWS S3 Console:

1. Create S3 bucket in the Amazon S3 Console

You may follow the simple steps below to create an S3 bucket in your AWS account. Also, refer to Amazon S3 Documentation Guide for more information.

1a. On the top-right corner of the AWS S3 console, select the Region in which you want to create the S3 bucket
1b. Choose Create Bucket
1c. Create a name for your S3 bucket, for example, papms3. Then click Create Bucket.

2. Upload the files in the S3 Bucket

To organize and upload your data files in AWS S3, follow below steps:

2a. For better organization, create a folder inside the S3 bucket you created. This is going to be the folder where your raw data will be stored, this can be in JSON, CSV or Parquet file.
2b. In this scenario, I named the folder inside the S3 bucket as inboundpapm. Click Create Folder.

2c. Go inside the newly created folder. Proceed to upload the raw data in AWS S3 by selecting Add Files.
2d. Click Upload to store the data securely in the S3 bucket.

3. Create access key and secret key

The steps below show how to generate Access Key and Secret Key pair in AWS for the SAP PaPM Cloud to securely connect and perform required operations in your AWS S3 bucket.


3a. Login to the AWS IAM Console and navigate to Users. Select the IAM user which has a sufficient privilege to access the S3 bucket.

 


3b. Inside the IAM User profile, go to Security Credentials
3c. Under the Access Keys section, click Create access key

3d. Finish the step by clicking Create Access Key again to generate new authentication credentials to connect AWS and SAP HANA Cloud. Optional: create a tag or a description for the access key.

3e. Ensure to save securely the Access Key and Secret Access Key information. Also, these credentials will be used in the latter step when we import the data from AWS S3 to SAP HANA Cloud.

 

4. Retrieve the AWS S3 Certificate


You will need to retrieve the AWS S3 certificate since at the latter step this certificate will be added to your SAP HANA Cloud instance to ensure trust configuration between AWS S3 and SAP HANA Cloud.


4a – 4b. Go to your AWS S3 bucket and in your browser click View Information – this will let you access the certificate specific to your AWS region.
4c. Once the certificate is displayed, export it to your desktop


4d. Open the certificate file using Notepad to view its details and save it in your local desktop.


Once AWS setup is completed, you can now proceed on the SAP HANA Cloud Database of your SAP PaPM Cloud.

SAP HANA Cloud 

Login to the HANA Database Cloud Central using administrator account of your SAP PaPM Cloud. The database settings for database schema, like SAP_PAPM_ADMIN, can be found in Database Settings.

1. Create a PSE (Personal Security Environment) for AWS S3

View all available PSEs in the SAP HANA Cloud then create a new one for AWS S3.

--- Check all available PSE in the SAP HANA Cloud
SELECT * FROM PSES;

--- Create PSE for AWS S3
--- CREATE PSE <PSE_NAME>;
CREATE PSE AWS_S3;

2. Create a root certificate for AWS S3 and add it in the SAP HANA Cloud

Obtain the root certificate that was done during the AWS S3 setup and add it to the SAP HANA Cloud naming it as AWS_S3_CERT and adding a comment for reference.

--- Add root certificate to SAP HANA Cloud 
--- CREATE CERTIFICATE <CERTIFICATE_NAME> FROM
--- '-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
MIID...g3bSMgHFzZM9...
-----END CERTIFICATE-----'
--- COMMENT 'S3';

CREATE CERTIFICATE AWS_S3_CERT FROM
'-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
MIIEfDC......292...
-----END CERTIFICATE-----'
COMMENT 'S3';


--- Check if AWS S3 Certificate is added in SAP HANA Cloud
--- SELECT * FROM CERTIFICATES WHERE CERTIFICATE_NAME = '<CERTIFICATE_NAME>';
SELECT * FROM CERTIFICATES WHERE CERTIFICATE_NAME = 'AWS_S3_CERT';

3. Add the AWS S3 certificate to the PSE

Link the certificate to the newly created PSE.

--- Add the certificate in PSE
--- ALTER PSE <PSE_NAME> ADD CERTIFICATE <CERTIFICATE_NAME>;
ALTER PSE AWS_S3 ADD CERTIFICATE AWS_S3_CERT;

4. Set the purpose of the PSE

Set the purpose of the PSE so it can be used for remote source connection. This step ensures SAP HANA Cloud recognizes and use the PSE for a secure communication with remote systems.

--- Set PSE as remote source
--- SET PSE <PSE_NAME> PURPOSE REMOTE SOURCE;
SET PSE AWS_S3 PURPOSE REMOTE SOURCE;

5. Import data from AWS S3 to SAP HANA Cloud

5a. In the SAP HANA Cloud Database Explorer of you SAP PaPM Cloud, go to Catalogs then right-click to Tables then select Import Data. This will open a window at the right side of the screen where you can configure the import settings.

 

5b – 5c. Under the Import Type section, select Import Data and proceed to Step 2. This will set the method for import the dataset to the SAP HANA Cloud.

5d – 5i: In Step 2. Import Source, specify the necessary fields to connect to AWS S3

Field Value
Import Data FromAmazon S3
Credential TypeSecret Key
S3 RegionSpecify the region of your AWS S3
S3 Path

Click the Compose button, then provide below details:

• Access Key:
Provide the Access Key retrieved from AWS S3
• Secret Key:
Provide the Secret Key retrieved from AWS S3
• Bucket Name:
Provide the name of your S3 bucket
• Object ID:
Provide the folder name and file name to be imported

Directory Type

Basic

File Format

Choose the appropriate file format of your imported data - CSV, JSON or Parquet

File has header in a row

If your file includes a header in the first row, ensure that option is checked. 

5j. In Step 3: Import Target, you need to decide whether you will be importing the data into a new table or append to an existing table.
5k. Click Step 4 to continue.

 

5l – 5m. In Step 4: Table Mapping, you can define how the fields from the source file will be paired or mapped to SAP HANA Cloud columns to ensure that data is aligned correctly with the database schema. After mapping, click Step 5 to proceed.

5n. In Step 5: Import, click Import to begin importing the dataset into SAP HANA Cloud. You will see a confirmation message saying “Import Successful” once the process completes.

6. Verify that the table has been created in the SAP HANA Cloud 

Finally, verify that the table has been created and the data has been imported correctly. Once verified, you can now continue with the data modelling in the SAP PaPM Cloud.

Let’s now proceed with the last step which takes place in the SAP PaPM Cloud. Whether you are using the Standard Model or the Universal Model, the goal remains the same: consume the data in SAP PaPM Cloud so it can be part of your modeling, calculation or allocations. I’ll walk you through on the steps for the inbound integration in Standard Model and Universal Model.

SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model

1. Create Connection in SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model

Establish a HANA schema connection following the procedure in Connections of the SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model.


Note: If no details appeared in the Authoring Schema, ensure to grant SELECT privilege to the container’s object owner.

  • Default Subscription (SAP HANA Runtime): Enter below SQL syntax:
GRANT SELECT ON SCHEMA “<ExternalUser>” to SAP_PAPM;
  • BYOD - SAP HANA Cloud: Go to Standard Model: Accessing Artifacts from External SAP HANA Cloud Schema for more information
  • BYOD - SAP Datasphere: Go to Standard Model: Accessing Artifacts of Space Schema from SAP Datasphere for more information

2. Create Modeling in the Environment

Once the connection has been established, user can now proceed to access an Environment and create Model Table HANA and link it to the connection created previously. Ensure to click Save and Activate the Environment.

3. View the database artifact in the Data Management Screen

Click Manage Data to view the data and underlying database artifact. If no data is shown, ensure that you have performed the grant SELECT privilege to SAP_PAPM schema.

 

SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model

1. Create Connection in SAP PaPM Universal Model

Access the Universal Model application, and create a HANA schema connection as described in HANA Schema.


Note: If no details appeared in the Target HANA schema, ensure to grant schema SELECT privilege to the container’s object owner SAP_PAPM_UM#OO described in SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model Application Help .

 

  • Default Subscription (SAP HANA Runtime): Enter below SQL syntax
-GRANT SELECT ON SCHEMA “<ExternalUser>” TO “SAP_PAPM_UM::external_privileges_role”; 

GRANT SELECT ON SCHEMA “<ExternalUser>” to SAP_PAPM#OO WITH GRANT OPTION;
  • BYOD - SAP HANA Cloud: Go to Universal Model: Accessing Artifacts from External SAP HANA Cloud Schema for more information 
  • BYOD - SAP Datasphere: Go to Universal Model: Accessing Artifacts of Space Schema from SAP Datasphere for more information

2. Create Modeling in the Environment

In the Models section of the created HANA schema section, which creates fields in the environment, choose Add Fields.

In the created HANA schema connection, which creates a model HANA in the environment, choose Sync Model.

Select the environment which contains the HANA schema connection, then choose Activate.

3. View database artifact in the Show Data

Access the Show Data link of the model HANA to see the data and the database artifacts. For more information, see Show Data.


And that wraps up this post!  You will now be able to use this data for complex calculation using function from SAP PaPM Cloud. in SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model and Universal Model.

Feel free to reach out or leave a comment if you have any questions or feedback. Until the next blogpost...😊

entry.title: SAP PAPM Cloud Standard Model - RFA's field customization feature
entry.content:
As you already know we have Remote Function Adapter (RFA) finance functions in our SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud – Standard Model (SAP PaPM Cloud SM) which allows posting of documents to S/4 HANA On Premise using Cloud Connector.  

These RFA finance function types like Finance General Ledger have been offered with its default static field list that can only be adjusted upon feature request - to request for new feature, visit https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/  

As much as the default list is mostly effective to majority of customers, there are still some customers having specific fields and posting needs. 

Due to this, SAP PAPM Cloud SM is now offering a flexible way for your administrators to add the desired finance fields.  

Yes, you've read it right! you can now add your customer's requested fields to have better posting experience. Let me show you how.

First, you need to identify the components that you need.

  1. In your S/4 HANA On Premise, Run SE37 
  2. Display the function module: BAPI_ACC_DOCUMENT_POST 
  3. Choose Tables tab 
  4. Then double click on Associated Type (e.g. BAPIACGL09) 

Now, in order to add these components to your RFA Function follow these steps. 

  1. Go to your SAP PaPM Cloud SM tenant 
  2. Choose Menu > Administration > Settings 
  3. Scroll down to Modeling Settings section 
  4. Then choose the Customize RFA Template button 

From here, you can add the components by choosing the Add Mapping Fields button and then maintain the required fields inside the Add Mapping Field to Your RFA Template popup dialog. For details about the required fields, visit  Modeling Settings on Help Portal.

NOTE: This option is currently available only for  “Finance General Ledger” and “Finance General Ledger Items” RFA types.

Few important reminders:

  1. Once the fields are added in the RFA Settings screen, modelers will need to add a new RFA function in the modeling for the new fields to be visible in the Mapping node.
  2. If you then decide to remove or delete a field that you have added, take note that this field won't be considered for any RFA functions that are using it.
  3. If in any case you are importing an environment coming from SAP PaPM On-Prem version, take note that you need to manually add any components that are new for your SAP PaPM Cloud SM system.

I hope the information provided in this blog post is able to help you start using this new screen and explore it by adding new components for your RFA postings. Until the next new features!

entry.title: The Value of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) in The Context of Business Steering
entry.content:
Last updated on 13th of Oct. 2025.

This blog post is a joint work of @Nektarios_Vasileiou33 and @BlazZabukovec .

Picture 1: SAP Analytics Cloud demo story example - Dashboard design by Daniel Davis

 

MOTIVATION

In today's fast-paced business world, the ability to effectively steer and lead an organisation is fundamental for achieving strategic goals and maintaining a competitive edge. A key success criterion is the capacity to fully harness and derive value from organisational data. Many companies struggle with data problems, such as fragmented information, outdated systems, and the super important task of preparing data for emerging technologies like AI. Recognising these challenges, we are excited to introduce a blog series dedicated to showcasing the substantial business value of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) in the context of planning and analytics.

The motivation behind this initiative is to provide a comprehensive exploration of how SAP BDC capabilities as essential instruments, facilitating robust strategic alignment and guiding effective decision-making processes across diverse organisational requirements. We aim to illustrate how SAP BDC, equipped with powerful data management, planning, analytics and innovative AI capabilities, empowers organisations with enhanced business steering agility by providing real-time insights, streamlined data management, and automated decision support – going from insights to action, helps mainly leaders guide their businesses with precision.

Our blog series will provide valuable insights for decision-makers seeking to harness SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) to enhance operational efficiency, optimise resource allocation, and achieve long-term objectives. By featuring detailed planning & analytics topics, the series will illustrate the transformative impact of SAP BDC in addressing the operational complexities of today’s business environment. This first introductory blog post will spotlight the strategic advantages of SAP BDC, particularly in the context of Business Steering, setting the stage for a deeper exploration of its benefits throughout the blog series.

There are several blog posts in the series that will cover advantages of SAP BDC in the context of business steering, so please stay tuned for the upcoming blogs:

  1. The Value of SAP BDC in the context of business steering (THIS BLOG POST)
  2. Planning & Analytics is an essential part of SAP BDC 
  3. Key Planning & Analytics components of SAP BDC
  4. Is AI going to “retire” a dashboard?
  5. Simulations, a game changer in today’s volatile world
  6. Extend existing planning scenarios of SAP BPC/BW-IP in SAP BDC
  7. Real-time steering with LIVE planning
  8. PaPM - The role of business calculation engine in business steering
  9. Self – service analytics and real time business steering
  10. Business steering powered by AI agents
  11. Leverage data products in the context of planning & forecasting
  12. Introducing AI/ML capabilities by SAP Databricks

CHALLENGES

The current global market situation is characterised by heightened volatility and uncertainty, driven by factors such as geopolitical tensions, inflationary pressures and rapid technological advancements. In this dynamic environment businesses face significant challenges like supply chain disruptions, rising and uncontrolled operational costs and the need for digital transformation to remain competitive.

Obviously, there is no one-size-fits-all solution to every challenge, but adopting a data-driven decision-making process provides significant advantages that can help organizations navigate complexities and respond more effectively to market dynamics. By relying on data to drive decisions, businesses can achieve greater accuracy and insight, which helps in identifying trends, understanding customer behaviours, and optimising operations. This approach enables companies to be more agile and responsive to changing conditions.

Every leader today feels the weight of growing complexity. CFOs balancing growth and profitability. CHROs managing talent in an evolving workforce. CIOs modernising IT while keeping innovation alive.

Picture 2: Challenges by CXO persona

But the true challenge lies in how these functions are increasingly interconnected. When one part of the business is disrupted, whether it’s a supply chain issue or a talent gap, the ripple effects are felt everywhere. To succeed, businesses need more than solutions for individual challenges, businesses need a way to align every function and unlock collective power.

Like Aristotle (apparently) once said: “THE WHOLE IS GREATER THAN THE SUM OF ITS PARTS”

Today’s complexity demands more than incremental fixes and silo apps/solutions. If we want to have benefits from AI and systems of agents collaborating across all functions, we need to have a solid foundation, where we can seamlessly combine applications, data, insights and AI into one ecosystem.

Just picture this example around Financial Planning (incl. forecasting & simulation), where we can develop a comprehensive financial snapshot while automating workflow tasks through agentic AI.

Picture 3: Forecasting & Simulation use case evolution

This is where we bring together all relevant data, like revenues, expenses, also across different scenarios, like actuals, plan & forecast. We also integrate all relevant external data, like different macro-economic KPIs, external market research data., etc. Based on identified key drivers/influencers of our business, we are going to define and perform different planning/forecasting scenarios. In the next step we are going to simulate and analyse impact of external drivers like inflation rate on our performance and identify the areas that will be impacted. Specialised analytics agent can propose potential mitigation strategies, like targeted promotions to drive customer demand, that can be further assessed & analysed. Based on this information we can decide for a certain course of actions that can be triggered by system of agents.

Picture 4: Risk analysis & mitigation strategies delivered by agentic AI

We can say with great confidence that our customers are not working in the area of visualising their data and that’s why SAP is also not in the business of visualising our customer’s data (even though we can do this is in a great way), but we are in a business of enabling the “Insights to Action” framework which is exactly what I have illustrated in the use case around financial planning powered by agentic AI.

Organizations striving to make data-driven decisions and a proper, also AI powered jump from insights to action, encounter several significant challenges. One major obstacle is seamlessly integrating data across various systems to extract valuable business insights. Additionally, ensuring data quality and integrity is crucial to maintaining trust in the decision-making process. Furthermore, building a comprehensive data foundation is essential for supporting the deployment of AI-based applications. Addressing these challenges requires robust data management strategies and innovative solutions to harness the full potential of data for valuable decision-making.

 

SAP's STRATEGY

To tackle these challenges, SAP developed the SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) to provide cloud services that empower organizations in navigating the complexities of data management and business steering process. SAP BDC serves as a unified platform, providing the necessary agility for effective business steering. SAP BDC offers a semantically rich, unified data environment that enhances operational efficiency and strategic decision-making capabilities. By centralising key business data from SAP and non-SAP sources into a unified semantic layer, SAP BDC unlocks insights, advanced analytics, and AI capabilities, empowering businesses to drive intelligent growth and innovation.

Picture 5: SAP Business Suite

SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) is a fully managed Software as a Service (SaaS) solution that unifies and governs all SAP data while seamlessly connecting with third-party data. The solution combines the capabilities of SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Business Warehouse, along with managed SAP Databricks. SAP BDC includes curated business-ready data products from SAP line of business applications leveraged by business-ready Intelligent Applications providing line-of-business leaders the context needed to make impactful decisions.

Picture 6: High level overview of SAP BDC services

Key Components of SAP Business Data Cloud:

SAP Datasphere: As the foundational element of SAP Business Data Cloud, SAP Datasphere provides a streamlined environment for data integration, warehousing, and governance. It features flexible integrated data tiering—comprising object, disk-based, and in-memory storage—ensuring a cost-effective persistence layer. Additionally, it offers sophisticated tools for analytical data modeling, transformation, and integration, enabling organizations to extract valuable insights and foster business innovation. Users can also utilize the framework to develop their own data products.

SAP Analytics Cloud: This component delivers cutting-edge analytics and planning capabilities while providing real-time insights powered by AI and machine learning. It integrates seamlessly with SAP Datasphere to offer a unified data analysis experience.

SAP Databricks: Through SAP's partnership with Databricks, data science capabilities are significantly enhanced. This collaboration facilitates advanced analytics and data science operations on both SAP and non-SAP data. Key features include ML Flows for machine learning operations, Mosaic AI for model training and serving, and Notebooks equipped with coding assistants and visualizations. The serverless Spark offerings aim to simplify big data processing, while replication-free access to SAP data products and integration with the Unity Catalogue further enrich the experience.

Intelligent Applications and Data Products: SAP Business Data Cloud emphasizes Intelligent Applications and SAP-managed Data Products. These ready-to-use, standardized business data objects and applications are managed by SAP, reducing the effort needed to build and operate analytical and data science applications. They promote data consistency and reusability, serving as modular, reusable assets for analytical models or AI/ML and planning workflows.

Unified Semantic Layer: Central to SAP Business Data Cloud is the unified semantic model, which standardizes data definitions across SAP and non-SAP systems. It offers simplified zero-copy data access via a standardized delta-share interface, supporting cross-domain analytics and AI applications. Additionally, it features a centralized cross-application catalog for data products and Intelligent Applications.

SAP BW: is integrated into SAP BDC, allowing SAP BW objects to be onboarded as data products. The SAP BW data products can be integrated in SAP Databricks to enable advanced analytics and data science use cases.

 

BUSINESS VALUE

SAP BDC delivers significant business value in the context of business steering, particularly within planning and analytics use cases. 

Enhanced Decision-Making: SAP BDC revolutionises decision-making by providing real-time access to integrated data. This SAP Analytics Cloud capability ensures that business leaders receive accurate and immediate insights, empowering them to make informed and strategic decisions. With this enhanced decision-making capacity, organizations can effectively anticipate market trends, adjust their strategies in response to evolving conditions, and maintain a competitive edge in their respective industries.

Comprehensive Data Integration: At the heart of SAP BDC is its ability to seamlessly integrate data from multiple sources, both SAP and non-SAP systems. This integration creates a unified view of the organisation's data landscape, supporting precise planning and predictive forecasting. By breaking down data silos and ensuring a holistic perspective, SAP BDC enables businesses to gain comprehensive insights into their operations and make well-rounded decisions. The data holistic perspective is fundamental for organizations to unleash AI across the entire data ecosystem.

Scalable Analytics and Planning Capabilities: One of the standout features of SAP BDC is its scalable analytics and planning capabilities. It allows businesses to conduct extensive analyses and simulations, uncovering valuable insights that aid in tailoring forecasts to specific scenarios. Whether it's understanding customer behavior or predicting market shifts, SAP Analytics Cloud robust analytics and planning capabilities in combination with SAP Databricks empower organizations to make data-driven predictions with unmatched precision and confidence.

Improved Efficiency and Agility: SAP BDC streamlines data integration and analytics processes, significantly enhancing efficiency and agility within organizations. By automating these crucial processes, leveraging data management features in SAP Datasphere, analytics in SAP Analytics Cloud and AI/ML workflows in SAP Databricks, it cuts down the time and effort needed for data preparation and analysis (replication free access of data and zero-copy). This efficiency allows teams to redirect their focus from operational concerns to strategic steering, driving more meaningful business results in less time.

Facilitated Innovation: Leveraging cutting-edge technologies such as artificial intelligence and machine learning, SAP BDC promotes innovation within organizations. Its cloud-based infrastructure ensures that businesses have access to the latest advancements, encouraging the exploration of new and innovative business models. This focus on facilitated innovation helps companies remain at the forefront of industry trends and continuously evolve their offerings.

Consistency in Data Governance: Ensuring data integrity and consistency is a critical component of SAP BDC's value proposition. The platform offers comprehensive data governance and quality management, providing reliable data integrity across planning and analytics activities. With consistent data definitions and governance, businesses can achieve accurate reporting and foster alignment across various departments, leading to cohesive planning strategies.

Seamless Collaboration: SAP BDC enhances collaboration by centralising data accessibility and sharing. Data Cataloguing, Data Sharing and Collaboration capabilities foster improved teamwork among departments and enables synchronised planning efforts and a guided steering process. With shared insights and aligned goals, teams can work together more effectively, driving unified strategies and achieving common objectives that benefit the entire organisation.

Strategic Resource Allocation: Through its predictive analytics and planning capabilities SAP Analytics Cloud and SAP Databricks, SAP BDC enables organizations to allocate resources more strategically. By delivering actionable insights, businesses can optimize operations, improve resource allocation, and enhance overall performance. This strategic approach ensures that resources are used efficiently to achieve maximum impact, driving profound business success.

Future-Proofing Autonomous Business Steering: By harnessing SAP AI agents within the trusted SAP BDC data foundation, the planning and business steering process is transformed from a static, periodic exercise into a dynamic, proactive function. These AI-driven insights empower companies to swiftly assess the potential impacts of various strategic options and make decisive actions. This approach allows businesses to anticipate market changes and respond efficiently, making strategic adjustments with confidence and precision.

 

CONCLUSION

SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) stands as a vital tool for organisations striving to enhance their decision-making capabilities, align strategic objectives, and navigate the complexities of modern business landscapes. In the era of AI, organizations require scalable and efficient data architectures to manage growing volumes of data and extract actionable insights leveraging advanced analytics, planning and machine learning capabilities. As we embark on this informative blog series, we invite you to stay tuned for our upcoming posts, where we will delve deeper into the AI, Planning & Analytics functionalities associated with SAP BDC and business steering use cases. Gain insights into how this powerful platform can drive your business forward, optimise operations, and help you achieve your strategic goals with confidence. Join us in exploring the transformative potential of SAP BDC and discover how it can be the catalyst for your organisation's growth and success.

 

CALL TO ACTION

To deepen your understanding of SAP Business Data Cloud, we invite you to explore the following links:

SAP Business Data Cloud Help

https://help.sap.com/docs/business-data-cloud?locale=en-US

Introducing SAP Business Data Cloud

https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/leveraging-sap-analytics-cloud-functionality-for-enterprise-planning/introducing-sap-business-data-cloud

Positioning SAP Business Data Cloud

https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/positioning-sap-business-data-cloud-1

entry.title: SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model: What’s New as of 2025-08-04?
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community!

It’s great to be back with another round of exciting updates. August brought some fresh changes to the SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud (SAP PaPM Cloud) Standard Model, and I’m here to walk you through what’s new.

Let’s jump right in and explore the highlights!

Environment screen

For users accessing the User Guide or reporting an incident, Built-in Support from SAP is now available directly in your tenants.
With this update, not only can you still access the User Guide and report incidents, but you can now also navigate to the SAP Community directly from the application.
As a result, the previous Help option will be replaced by this new built-in support experience.

For more information, please visit Integrated Support Experience: SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model with SAP Built-in Support.

Modeling screen

Good news for modelers!
To improve efficiency, the Activate button on the Modeling screen now comes with extended functionality - it will first save any changes made to the modeling configuration and then proceed with activation, just like how it works in SAP PaPM On-Premise version.

Report Management screen | Chat with AI copilot - Joule

A new feature in SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model has been enhanced in the Settings and Report Management screens to enable AI-powered insights via Joule.
To start using Joule in the application, some initial setup is required in SAP BTP. These steps are described in the SAP Business AI (Joule) Setup.
After the setup, simply go to the Settings screen and, under the new “Joule AI Settings” section, select your SAP AI Core destination and choose the AI model you want to use.

Once configured, Joule becomes available in the Report Management screen, allowing users to ask questions about the report and receive instant answers from AI.

More details on how to configure Joule in SAP BTP and how to use it later in the Report Management screen can be found in the SAP PaPM Cloud blog post SAP PaPM Cloud SM: Enhancing Report Management with the power of generative AI copilot – Joule, or by visiting our Application Help portal SAP Business AI (Joule) Setup.

Administration | Settings screen

Administrators and modelers can now add additional mapping fields to their Remote Function Adapters using the new RFA template. To do this, simply navigate to the Settings screen and select Customize RFA Template.

For more information, please refer to Application Help portal Modeling Settings or visit SAP PAPM Cloud Standard Model - RFA's field customization feature.

Administration | Content Management screen

To help administrators avoid accidental overwrites, the Content Management screen now displays a warning message when the “Overwrite” option is set to “Yes”, alerting users that changes from the current environment version will be lost.

That wraps up this month’s round of updates! Hopefully, these new features make your day-to-day work a little smoother.
Stay tuned, stay engaged, and see you in the next one!

entry.title: SAP PaPM Cloud SM: The New Data Management Screen – Part 1/2
entry.content:
Hello Everyone!  

I’m here to share with you the exciting new features and enhancements in SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud (PaPM) Standard Model made available and can already experience in your SAP PaPM SM tenants.  

One of the most used applications currently offered by SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud - SM is the  Show screen. As an overview, the Show screen in PaPM Cloud – SM displays the function results in a tabular form where the users can do filtering, selections, pivoting and groupings that can be used for reporting.

Apart from displaying data, the users can also perform data maintenance via the Show screen of an Editable Query function and via Manage Data of a Model Table function with Transport Data set to YES/NO and of course downloading of data for all functions. 

For your reference, you can revisit SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model: What’s New as of 2024-01-03? 

In this blog post, I am thrilled to walk you through the newest enhancements in the application for better user experience in terms of data maintenance. Before we begin, please note that all scenarios discussed in this blog post will be from the perspective of the Model Table function. A separate blog post will be released later, focusing on the Editable Query function, which will cover analytical privileges, fixed selections, and data slice locking as well as the usage of display options in master data fields.  

Before we get started, this topic will be divided in two parts. Part 1, will focus mainly in the UI changes for the new Data Management screen as well as for the uploading and downloading of a file, and Part 2 will be focused on the different scenarios while uploading in the new Data Management Screen. 

So, let’s get started! 

In line with the introduction of Manage Data for the Model Table function, the Data Maintenance screen is now referred to as the Data Management screen which is already available in the App help portal.

The users can maximize the full benefit of the new Data Management screen when uploading and downloading files using a Model Table or an Editable Query function with its optimized performance. 

Access to the Data Management screen 

Prerequisites: Access to Data Management screen requires certain roles to be configured beforehand.  

For reference, you may visit the following blog posts and documentation: 

  • Role Overview in SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model (Part 1/2)  
  • Role Overview in SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model (Part 2/2) 
  • Help Portal Role Template for Standard Model. 

Previously, authorized users could access, manage and/or maintain data in the Show and Analyze screens through two different buttons.

Upon access to the Show and Analyze screens, the URL parameters display: 

Show screen:

Analyze screen:

With the new Data Management screen, Show and Analyze screens were merged into one screen, which can be accessed via Manage Data button.

Users can now analyze or view data in pivot by toggling on and off the Pivot button under Settings.

Upon initial access to the Data Management screen of a Model Table function, users will see the user interface and the following header buttons:

  1. Menu button 
  2. Collapse Header 
  3. General (App-Refresh) 
  4. Edit  
  5. Validation counter 
  6. Layout 
  7. Upload & Download 
  8. Settings
  9. Columns
  10. Filters  
  11. Drag and drop button 
  12. Function Description and Total Rows Count 
  13. Message Logs footer 

If the Model Table function doesn’t have an existing dataset, the user will see the Drag and Drop interface as an initial view.

Uploading File  

In the Data Management screen, the authorized users, referenced in the prerequisites can upload files (CSV and XLSX) with malware scanning limit of 400MB in two ways:

  1. Via Upload File – The users can upload a file by choosing the Upload file button in the Upload & Download header. 
  2. Via Drag and Drop – The users can simply drag the desired file from the user’s local file manager and drop it to the designated area on the screen.  

Note: Only csv and xlsx files are supported during upload and a validation error “Unsupported file type. Please use .csv, .xlsx.” will be encountered in case the user attempts to upload other local file format.

Once data upload is confirmed, the Data Upload window with the following fields sections below should be maintained and/or defined.  

  1. Number Format – this dropdown list will allow the user to choose different number format options 
  2. Date Format – this dropdown list will allow the user to choose different date format options 
  3. Time Format – this dropdown list will allow the user to choose different time format options 
  4. Field Delimiter – this field will only be available if the file to be uploaded is a csv file which allows the user to choose the field delimiter accordingly. Examples of field delimiter available are: Comma, Semicolon, Tab, Space and Pipe. 
  5. Skip header row in file during import
    - if this option is checked, the header row of the local file to be uploaded will be skipped
    - if this option is unchecked, the header row of the local file to be uploaded will be included during upload
  6. Add data from file to existing this – if this option is checked the data to be uploaded will just be added in the existing dataset
  7. Overwrite the existing data –if this option is checked, the data to be uploaded will overwrite the existing data
    - Overwrite filtered data with data from file - his option becomes active when you apply filters in the Data Management screen. If you check this option, the uploaded data overwrites the filtered data. 
  8. Cancel upload– if this button is chosen, the Data Upload window will be closed 
  9. Upload – if this button is chosen, the upload process will start

Note: The format settings to be defined in the Data Upload window should be aligned with the format of the local file that is to be uploaded. After successful upload, the formats will obtain the formats maintained in User Preferences application. 

To cover the different scenarios for uploading, please check our Data Management screen – Part 2/2. 

Downloading File  

The data download options for the new Data Management screen were enhanced for the users to be able to have a clear view of what is going to be downloaded. Data download can be performed in different ways for both csv and xlsx files with below field sections:

  1. Complete dataset – this option allows the user to download all number of rows considering the applied formatting (columns selection, filtering, and sorting). This option is not limited to the loaded and/or visible data and has the option to enable/disable applied formats. 
      - "Apply formatting checked": this will allow the user to download the dataset including the applied formatting in the screen
      - "Apply formatting unchecked": this will allow the user to download the whole dataset and will disregard the applied formatting in the screen  
  2. Visible dataset – this option allows the user to download only all loaded visible data shown in the screen. This is also the only download option available when Pivot Mode is enabled. 
    Note: The dataset is being loaded by batches of 500 rows
  3. Tooltip messages – hovering over these tooltip messages will give the user an information about Target download options
  4. File Format – If there are file formats available in the system, they can be used when downloading data. 
  5. Download CSV – this option will allow the user to download the file in CSV format 
  6. Download XLSX – this option will allow the user to download the file in XLSX format

Note: Just a heads-up, when Data Management screen is in Pivot mode On, the UI of Data Download will be a little bit different, since only the Visible dataset option will be available for use, and with this the Download with File Format will be disabled as well.  

 

And that’s it! That concludes my blog post. I hope you enjoy the new features of the new Data Management screen and be able to help you work efficiently in managing your data. To always be in the loop for more exciting news, please follow and check the tag PaPMCloudSM.

entry.title: SAP PaPM Cloud SM: The New Data Management Screen – Part 2/2
entry.content:
Hello Everyone!

As promised, after The New Data Management Screen – Part 1/2 blog post, I’m back with Part 2/2 blog post, where we will focus on the different scenarios for uploading in the new Data Management screen.

So, without further delay, let’s get started.

Upload Overwrite Warnings

To help prevent accidental data loss, the Data Management screen now includes a clear warning whenever an upload overwrite option is selected.

Depending on your chosen upload method (Options Overwrite all existing data with data from file or Overwrite filtered data with data from file), you'll be notified if:

  1. All existing data will be overwritten, or
  2. Only specific rows (X rows currently displayed in the table- filtered ones) will be replaced.

This added layer of confirmation helps ensure you're always aware of the impact before proceeding with an upload.

Let me show you some example scenarios below to visualize the new UI.

Prerequisite: User should access an empty Data Management screen of Model Table or editable Query function.

SCENARIO 1: Uploading via Upload file in an empty screen

In case that user is to upload file in an empty screen, the Data Upload window will pop up after choosing a file.

  1. In the Data Management screen, choose Upload file button from the header.
  2. Choose a file from the File Manager, then choose Open.
  3. Maintain the appropriate format settings (Number Format, Date Format, Time Format) in the Data Upload window.
  4. Choose Confirm.

 

SCENARIO 2: Upload via Drag & Drop with an empty screen

User can either click anywhere on the Drag and drop interface or drag the local file and drop it to the designated area on the screen.

  1. In the Data Management screen, click anywhere on the Drag and drop interface or simply drag the local file and drop it to the screen.
  2. Maintain the appropriate format settings (Number Format, Date Format, Time Format) in the Data Upload window.
  3. Choose Confirm.

SCENARIO 3: Uploading via Upload File/Drag and drop with an existing data

In case the user uploads a file with existing data on the screen, the Drag and drop window will pop up.

  1. In the Data Management screen, choose Upload file button from the header.
  2. Click anywhere on the Drag and drop window or simply drag and drop file to the window.
  3. Maintain the appropriate format settings (Number Format, Date Format, Time Format) in the Data Upload window.
  4. Choose Confirm.

SCENARIO 4: Uploading with invalid data formats

In case that user defined incorrect data formats (number, time, and date formats) in the Data Upload window, or if the local file uploaded has invalid data values such as incorrect data length or out of master data, the user will be redirected to the Upload Preview tab.

While in the Data Management screen, the Go To -> Upload Preview button will be visible in the upper right of the screen once there’s an existing upload draft which redirect the user to Upload Preview tab.

Note: In case user maintained incorrect field delimiter (for csv file), the user will not be redirected to the Upload Preview tab, instead an error will be encountered, and upload will not push through.

In the Upload Preview, the user will see the following header buttons and info:

  1. Finalize & Discard
    • Finalize data upload – this button allows the user to save all the corrected data. Once chosen, the Finalize data upload warning message window will pop up where the user can choose to either finalize the data upload or cancel the action.
    • Discard data upload – this button allows the user to cancel the upload draft. If in any case there is already corrected data, the Discard data upload warning message window will pop up where the user can choose to either Continue or Cancel the discard action.
  2. Go To -> Manage Data – Choose this Go To button if you wish to go back to the Data Management screen.
  3. Validation table information – this section presents the number of rows to be corrected as well as the valid rows to be uploaded. Note that this changes accordingly once the user corrects row cells with valid data.
  4. Field column headers settings:
    - Replace in all rows -  this setting allows the user to correct values in bulk in each field column
    - Header column settings - this setting allows the user to perform column sizing and column pinning 
  5. Columns Panel – this panel helps the user to perform column management of fields in the data table.

SCENARIO 5: Automatic saving of Upload Preview draft

In case of unexpected termination, for example: browser/system shutdown or the user accidentally accesses a different application screen, the upload draft is automatically saved and can be accessed by the user who initiated the upload process.

In this way, the user won’t have to worry about losing the draft that was already corrected in the Upload Preview. A warning message “Upload for this table hasn't been finalized yet. Go to upload preview” will pop-up or Go to -> Upload Preview is enabled in the header as an indication that there’s an existing upload draft.

Once the user chooses any of the upload preview links, user will be redirected to the upload preview tab where draft will be present. In this screen the user is allowed to edit the data to correct the erroneous data.

Note: Once the last erroneous value is edited, the upload will be automatically finalized, and the user will be redirected to Data Management screen.

SCENARIO 6: Locking Mechanism in Upload Preview

Data Management is made more efficient with its locking mechanism feature during the upload process in the Data Management of the same Model Table, editable Query function or any related Queries derived from the same Model Table, for example:

       6A: User A has started an upload process in the Data Management or updating upload draft in Upload Preview and User B attempts to upload a file in the same function, User B will encounter a warning message pop-up “Another user is editing this data. Upload action is not possible now.”

6B: In case that User A will be on idle or is not changing anything in the Upload Preview, an active timer message window “Finalize data upload” will pop-up after 12 minutes of being idle and/or inactive to inform the user of the remaining time (3 minutes) before the draft will be discarded automatically. User A will have two options:

  1. Finalize Upload – this option is equivalent to the Finalize data upload button from the header button finalizing upload and saving all valid data rows.
  2. I need more time – this option allows the user to reset the already calculated idle time, providing an additional 15 minutes before the draft is discarded.

User A will be redirected to the Upload Preview. At this point, uploading of file is not possible for User B.

Note: Upload action will trigger application run type: DATA_IMPRT in the Application log monitor, if the user is still in the Upload Preview, the status will show “Awaiting User Input”. The status will change to Success if the draft is successfully saved or Abort if the upload draft is discarded.

SCENARIO 7: Upload with file formats

Just like in old Show screen, you can upload CSV and XLSX files in the Data Management screen using predefined file formats. This makes managing your data quicker and more accurate, especially when working with different date, time, and number formats.

Previously, in the Show screen, clicking the Upload icon allowed you to select a file from your local, and then a dialog would appear where you could choose the sheet (for XLSX) or specify the file format to be used during the upload.

Now, when you go to the Data Management screen and click Upload, you’ll first be taken to a Select File Format dialog. From here:

  • You can either choose Continue without file format, where upon clicking Continue, you will be redirected to Data Upload screen, where you can choose the predefined formats already existing in the system (same as the ones available in User Preferences).

Note: Always remember that in case Number, Date and Time Formats are incorrect (not the same format as the XLSX/CSV file to be uploaded) the Upload Preview will be triggered, since these formats need to be aligned with the file to be uploaded.

  • You can choose an existing file format from the dropdown (by clicking the arrow next to “File Format”). Once you click Continue, you’ll land on the familiar Data Upload screen, where you can finalize your upload.

Note: The Data Upload UI will also change accordingly, in case the user is uploading a XLSX or CSV file.

Let’s look at some common upload scenarios while using file formats:

  1.  Uploading a CSV with the correct file format 

If your file format settings match the CSV content — great! The upload will complete successfully with no issues.

       2. Uploading a CSV with the wrong file format

If the file format selected in the Data Upload on Data Management screen doesn’t match the data in the CSV to be uploaded, the system will detect it and trigger the Upload Preview screen.

In this scenario let’s say that the thousand and the decimal separator are not matching between the file format in the modeling and the data of the CSV to be uploaded.

Upon uploading the CSV file this will trigger the Upload Preview screen, since the file format in the system do not match the formats used in the file. You’ll be able to see exactly where the mismatches are, so you can correct them in Upload Preview or simply cancel the upload and adjust your file format settings to match the required ones from the file.

Note: Make sure your Field Delimiter, Date, Time, Timestamp Formats and Thousand and Decimal Separators all match what's in your file.

       3. Uploading XLSX with correct file format

If the format settings match the content of your XLSX file, the upload will work seamlessly.

Note: For XLSX files, the Field Delimiter setting in the file format is not taken into consideration.

       4. Uploading XLSX with the wrong file format

If the file format selected in the Data Upload doesn’t match the data in the XLSX to be uploaded, the system will detect it the Upload Preview screen will be triggered.

In this scenario, let’s say that the date format is not matching between the file format in the modeling and the data of the XLSX to be uploaded.

Like what happen when uploading a CSV with incorrect format, the data can be edited in the Upload Preview or cancel the upload and adjust the file format settings to match the required ones from the file.

Note: Always pay attention to the Date and Time Formats applied in the File Formats section in the Modeling. DD/MM/AAAA or yyyy as a date format or hh as time format will not be accepted since this is not supported according to HANA docs. The use of file formats can be applied in the same way in both Pivot mode off and on.

And this is it for this blog post. I hope you enjoyed the new features.

Watch out for new features for the Data Management screen to be released soon.

Stay tuned for more exciting news by following the tag PaPMCloudSM.

entry.title: Data Management Screen: Master Data Upload in in Editable Query & Understanding Display Options
entry.content:
Uploading master data values in the Data Management screen can be a smooth process - if you understand how the system handles Display options like ID, description, and the combination of ID and description. Whether you're uploading internal or external master data, small details like duplicate descriptions or Pivot mode ON can make a big difference in how your file is processed.

In this blog post, we’ll walk you through the different upload scenarios and explain how the system behaves in each case, so you can avoid common errors and make your uploads error-free. Let’s dive in!

Master data Display Options in Context Menu

If you've spent some time in the Show screen, you might have noticed a handy setting in the context menu for master data fields within a Query function. It’s called Display, and it lets you choose how master data values are shown — whether it’s just the ID, just the description, or ID and description.

This same flexibility is available in the new Data Management screen as well! Whether your master data is managed internally or pulled from external sources (like Queries), you can customize how it’s displayed to suit your needs — making your data easier to understand and work with.

The image below highlights two ways to work with master data in SAP PaPM Cloud. You can adjust internal master data right from the modeling screen (on the left side) or pull in external master data using queries (left side). Curious to dive deeper on this subject? Check out the blog post SAP PaPM Cloud: Introduction of Query-Based Master Data and Hierarchy for a full breakdown.

If you want to customize how master data appears, just right-click on any master data value within the Query function of the Data Management screen to open the context menu. From there, select Display, and choose one of the available options:

  • ID – The master data ID values are displayed in the screen (option set by default)
  • Description – The set master data descriptions are displayed in the screen
  • ID and Description – The concatenation of both ID and Description master data are displayed together in the screen

Once selected, your data will instantly update based on your choice — and you'll see the new display reflected right away in the screen.

The display setting also applies when you download your data as an XLSX or CSV file. So, whichever option you’ve might selected – ID, Description or ID and Description combined- your downloaded file will reflect the same format.

Note: By default, the Data Management screen will always show ID values for master data. So even if you switch the display to Description or ID and Description, once you refresh the screen, it'll go back to showing just the ID.

Upload Master Data with Different Display Options

Now let’s check how the upload process behaves depending on the display setting you use. We’ll check different scenarios so you can see what to expect.

SCENARIO 1- Uploading using master data IDs in editable Query

This is the most straightforward scenario when trying to upload master data values, either internal or external (Query-based).

As long as the master data values IDs in your file match those in the system, the upload will be successful, and the uploaded data will be reflected on the screen based on your chosen upload method.

SCENARIO 2- Uploading using master data descriptions in editable Query

Let’s now check the scenario where you can upload the master data values set with description.

The system can recognize the descriptions as long as they match the defined master data and the upload will go through just fine.

However, there’s a catch.

If your master data contains duplicate descriptions, things get tricky. For example, if two different IDs (like CHMD11 and CHMD15) share the same description (CHARMD11), the system won’t know which one to use. All the values highlighted in yellow have duplicated descriptions.

Now, in the new Data Management screen, after successful upload, you will receive a warning message for each master data field, indicating that the duplicates may lead to unexpected results, as the system cannot reliably determine the correct ID.

That’s why uploading by description alone is not recommended if you have duplicated descriptions in your master data.

 

SCENARIO 3 – Uploading using master data ID and description combined in editable Query

Here’s where things get interesting.

Previously in Show screen, uploading files that used a combination of ID and description would cause errors—you’d need to manually adjust the data before it could be accepted.

Now with the enhanced Data Management screen this action is possible.

The system can now recognize this combination of ID and description as a valid master data value making the upload process safer, even if you have duplicate descriptions in your master data. This new feature can be used in both internal and external master data.

Note: Just always make sure the ID and description values match exactly with what’s in your master data. If they don’t, the system will trigger validation errors.

If you're using Pivot mode ON on the Data Management screen, the behavior is basically the same as when Pivot mode is OFF. So, whether you’re uploading with ID, description, or combination of both, the same rules apply.

The entries highlighted in red in the image below, represent Nodes—placeholders created to accommodate hierarchical structures. These Nodes impact the Data Management screen when Pivot mode is activated. Please note that uploading Nodes is not allowed, as they are not valid master data values.

In case you have hierarchies applied in on your Data Management screen with Pivot mode ON, and you download that specific display, upon uploading, this will always trigger the Upload Preview screen, since the nodes are not accepted as master data values.

No matter which method you use, always double-check your file against the master data in the system before uploading. Keeping IDs and descriptions aligned will save you from a lot of headaches later!

And this is it.

Thank you so much and keep posted for new blog posts in our tag PaPMCloudSM.

entry.title: Data Management Screen: Managing Analytic Privileges, Fix Selections & Data Slice Locking
entry.content:
In previous blog posts, Data Management screen Part 1/2 and Part 2/2, we showed you the newest enhancements in the SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud Standard Model (SAP PaPM Cloud SM) application for better user experience regarding the new Data Management screen, focused on the Model Table function perspective.

In this blog post we will highlight the enhancements featuring editable Query function and maximizing its potential when applying Object-Based Authorizations, such as Analytic Privileges, Fix Selections and Data Slice Locking.

Upload and Edit in Editable Query When Analytic Privileges Are Applied

In the blog post “SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud: Analytic Privileges”, we explored a significant feature known as Analytic Privileges. This feature, part of the Object-Based Authorization in SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud Standard Model, enables specific users to have Read and Write access to master data. Users granted with Read Access can view the master data, while those with Write Access can modify the data records associated with it in the Input/Output Activity (editable Query).

In this blog post, we will demonstrate how to utilize the new Data Management screen for uploading data when Analytic Privileges are set.

Prerequisites:

  • Create teams with designated users.
  • Establish a characteristic field with master data values.
  • Assign teams Read and Write Access to the relevant master data values, as illustrated in the example below.

Previously, in Show screen, when users tried to upload a file where Analytic Privileges were applied, even if the user has Write Access privileges to some of the values, the upload will always fail.

In the new Data Management screen blog posts Part 1/2 and Part 2/2, we introduced this revamped screen, highlighting its fresh user interface and exciting new features. One of the standout improvements is the streamlined file upload process, which also affect the upload when Analytic Privileges are applied.

Now, with this new screen enhancement, the users can upload a file (CSV or XLSX) in the Data Management screen, where Analytic Privileges are applied in an editable Query on the Modeling screen.

Let’s check the different scenarios for it:

SCENARIO 1 – Upload of a file (CSV or XLSX) when Analytic Privileges are applied

In this scenario, a user in TEAM 1 team will upload a file in an editable Query, with the upload restricted to values where the user has both Read and Write Access (all the values in Hierarchy Name H1), as well as the values that do not have Read nor Write Access.

Additionally, there are two specific cases where the user has Read Access, but lacks Write Access: CHMD1-TEAM 2 and CHMD6-TEAM 1. This will allow the user to see the data, however, the user will not be able to edit it.

Users can easily monitor their uploads through log messages in the footer and in the logs of Application Monitor screen (only accessible for users with APPLICATION_MONITOR READ and SYSTEM_USER_ALL roles). These provide clear feedback, indicating how many rows were automatically skipped due to non-compliance with the current Analytic Privileges. This means that only (Total – X) rows will be successfully imported, while the X rows that were skipped are those that the user do not have Read/Write Access to it.

The user in TEAM 1 can successfully upload 9 rows and will skip 3 rows (CHMD6, CHDM7 and CHMD8 since these values are assigned to TEAM 2).

However, if a user from TEAM 2 accesses the same editable Query, the displayed data will differ because of the Analytic Privileges assigned to each user. This not only applies to the original data already included in the editable Query (highlighted in green in the image below), but as well to the newly uploaded values (highlighted in yellow). This means that from the 9 rows uploaded from user in TEAM 1, user in TEAM 2 will only see 6 (the ones allowed due to the set Analytic Privileges).

Note: If a user assigned in TEAM 2 team  tries to edit value CHMD1, this will never be possible. The user has Read Access to this value although they don’t have Write Access to edit that value, or to edit other value into CHMD1.

SCENARIO 2- Upload with “Overwrite all existing data with data from file” checked

When importing data into an editable Query with Analytic Privileges applied to a Master Data value, only the data for which the user has the appropriate Analytic Privileges will be modified when using the Overwrite Upload option. This also applies to the overwrite of data in the input Model Table.

The user in TEAM 1, upon uploading in the Editable Query, can see in the log messages that 3 rows were automatically skipped, and 9 rows were successfully uploaded. The values CHMD7 and CHMD8 are not present in the Editable Query because the user in TEAM 1 does not have Read Access for those. And although the user can still see CHMD6 (due to their Read Access), this value is not present from the performed upload (since the user lacks Write Access to perform this action), but instead this value persists from the original data which was not overwritten.

Moreover, the upload overwritten in the editable Query also takes effect in input Model Table. This means, that if a user in TEAM 1 does not have Read nor Write Accesses to CHMD7 or CHMD8 and although has Read Access to CHMD6 but lacks Write Access for it, the upload “Overwrite” option in editable Query will not remove these values in input Model Table (values highlighted in red in the example below).

Upload When Fix Selection Is Applied in Editable Query

The fix selection allows to filter the Query output, and the data is displayed based on the values defined in the selection. This action can be configured for all Characteristic-type fields in the Query Element. To know more about Fix Selection in Query Element, kindly check the Help Portal.

After the fix selection is defined, the editable Query function can be further used in the Process Template and Process Instance in the Input/Output Activity.

SCENARIO 1- Upload of a file (CSV or XLSX) when Fix Selections are applied

After defining the fix selections in the Query Element, save and activate the changes, then choose Data Management in the header and confirm the Query output. In the Data Management screen, choose Upload under the header Upload & Download header section, and after selecting the correct formats in the Data Upload window, choose Confirm.

The upload will be successful and the rows that are not compliant with the fix selections applied will be automatically skipped.

Note: If uploading data to an editable Query function and there is Fix Selection maintained in its Query Elements, only the data associated to the Fix Selection would be replaced when uploading using the “Overwrite” option “SAP PaPM Cloud: What's New as of 2022-09-26?”.

SCENARIO 2 - Upload a file where all rows are skipped

But what happens when a user tries to upload a file where all the rows will be skipped, since they are not compliant with the applied fix selections?

This scenario is not allowed, and therefore an error message will be displayed stating that no rows were inserted as well as the number of rows skipped during the upload.

Upload Without and With Erroneous Data in Editable Query When Data Slice Locking Is Applied

In the blog post titled "SAP PaPM Cloud: What’s New as of 2022-12-19?", we discussed an important feature where users can lock and unlock data slices based on specific combinations of Process Selection characteristic field values within the underlying Model Tables. This functionality is part of the editable Query feature used in the Input/Output Activity on the Process Management screen.

If you're looking to utilize this capability, simply follow the steps outlined below:

On the Process Management screen:

  • Select the values under the process selections.
  • Save the changes.
  • Select the process main task and lock the selected values.

Before in Show screen when Data Slice Locking was applied, the upload process was not possible.

Now, with the new enhancements in Data Management screen, the upload is also possible when Data Slice Locks are applied. To be able to perform this action, simply drag and drop your file into the designated area on the selected Input/Output Activity. Select the appropriate number, date, and time formats (according to the file to be uploaded) and field delimiter (in case of a CSV file), and watch as the upload begins and finishes seamlessly

I will show you now different scenarios where the data slice locking can be applied when uploading data.

 

SCENARIO 1: Upload of a file (CSV or XLSX) when Data Slice Locks are applied

Similar to what is happening to the upload when Analytic Privileges or Fix Selections are applied, the number of rows that were successfully uploaded and the ones that were skipped because they are not compliant with the data slice locking applied can be visualized in the log messages footer.

Note: If you are importing/uploading files to an Input/Output Activity, with the “Overwrite” option selected and Data Slice Locking is maintained in the Process Instance properties, the data associated with the Data Slice Locking will not be replaced.

Upon upload, the data will be updated accordingly in the corresponding editable Query used in the Input/Output Activity on the Modeling screen, as well as the input Model Table.

SCENARIO 2: Upload a file with erroneous data and values not compliant with the Data Slice Lock applied

If the user uploads a file with erroneous values, the Upload Preview screen will be triggered and here you can make necessary edits. After correcting all the erroneous data, the upload draft will be automatically finalized and your data saved in Data Management screen.

Let’s imagine now that while making these edits, one of the values that was corrected turns out to not quite fit with the Data Slice Lock currently in place.

You might have noticed the value highlighted in yellow (the A-value) from the image above. This is not an erroneous value, since is in accordance with the allowed values for this specific field, however, is not compliant with the Data Slice Lock applied.

In this case, two processes for skipping rows during upload due to Data Slice Lock can be implemented:

A- Automatic Skipping: Rows without erroneous data that are automatically skipped if their values do not comply with the current Data Slice Lock.

B- Upload Preview Skipping: Rows containing erroneous data can be edited in the Upload Preview screen and if they do not align with the applied Data Slice Lock, they will be also skipped.

Note: For this scenario, the user can only track these actions and any relevant messages that provides a clear visibility into the upload process, as shown below.

  1. The first highlighted sequence displayed in the picture above, illustrates a scenario where the Upload Preview screen is triggered due to erroneous data that requires editing before the upload can be completed. Notably, a warning message appears indicating that two rows were skipped. These rows were not flagged for erroneous data; rather, they were excluded because they did not comply with the current data slice lock. As a result, these two rows were not included in the Upload Preview.
  2. The second highlighted sequence another warning message is displayed. This time, it informs the user that one uploaded row was skipped due to non-compliance with the current data slice lock. This issue arose when the user edited a value that conflicted with the established compliance rules. Consequently, this row was also omitted from the upload process, resulting in a successful upload of only 5 rows.

Note: When user is trying to download the data where Data Slice Locking is applied, the option “Complete dataset” can be used with or without applying formatting, and the user will be able to easily spot the differences based on the filters applied.

One last thing to keep in mind: everything we’ve covered about uploading with Data Slice Lock also applies to the Model Table that serves as an input function to the editable Query where the Data Slice Lock is applied. So, if you’re uploading data directly to a Model Table and Data Slice Locking is in place, the upload behavior will work just like it does for the editable Query.

And this is it.

Hope that you enjoyed reading our blog post. Stay tuned for more updates and if you like to read previous blog post kindly visit the tag PaPMCloudSM.

entry.title: SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model: Extended Environment Access Level Functionality
entry.content:
Hi Dear Community Members!

Previously in the blogpost SAP PaPM Cloud SM: Introducing the Environment Access Management Screen we introduced you to Environment Access Management (EAM) Screen where administrators can set an environment access level security to control the visibility to their environments by setting them as either “Public” or “Private” which ensures that only authorized users have access to it.

To unlock its full potential, SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud – Standard Model (SAP PaPM Cloud SM) is glad to announce the extended environment access level functionality where administrators can now start setting the environment access level from Environment Screen (Main) and Content Management. in this blogpost, I will walk you through the steps on how to do it from Creation, Editing, and even Copying of an environment to setting environment access level when importing a content to your tenant.

Before we proceed, it is important to take note that admin users must have the ENVIRONMENTS_ACCESS_ALL role which will play a crucial part in this extended functionality.

Let’s get started!

In the Environment and Content Management screens, we know that to manage environments your user must have at least the ENVIRONMENTS and CONTENTS role.

But now, if your user has a combined role ENVIRONMENTS_ACCESS_ALL, you will have this additional Access option.

Although this access option is comparable to what is presently available on the EAM screen, you can now define an environment to be either public or private and assign authorized teams from the moment it is created, edited, copied, or imported.

Create a private environment

  1. In the environment screen choose Add button
  2. Choose Environment
  3. In the Add Environment window, maintain the following:
    1. Environment ID
    2. Environment Version
    3. Description
  4. In Access, by default public is chosen in this option but if you switch to Private, as an admin you will be able to choose and assign the Teams that will be authorized to see and access this environment.
  5. Then choose Add

Edit a public environment to private

  1. In the environment screen choose your environment
  2. Choose Edit
  3. In the Edit Environment window, choose the access level as Private  
  4. Choose the Authorized Teams
  5. Then choose Edit

Note: Private environments can also be edited as public, just choose Public in access.

Copy a public environment as private

  1. In the environment screen choose your environment
  2. Choose Add button, then choose Environment from
  3. In the Copy Environment window, maintain the following:
    1. Environment ID
    2. Environment Version
    3. Description
  4. In Access, by default public is chosen in this option but if you switch to Private, as an admin you will be able to choose and assign the Teams that will be authorized to see and access this environment.
  5. Then choose Copy

Note: Private environments can also be copied as another private environment and the admin will have an option to either retain or change the assigned authorized teams.

Now, let’s take a look in Content Management screen. First thing that you will notice is a new column called Access which indicates if an environment in the list is public or private.

Let us understand how import works with this environment access level functionality!

Import a public environment and make it as private

  1. In the Content Management, choose the content that you want to import
  2. Choose Import button
  3. In the Import Environment, maintain the following:
    1. Environment ID
    2. Environment Version
    3. Activate: Yes/No
    4. In the Access, choose Private
    5. Assign the Authorized Teams
  4. Then choose Import as New

Note: Private environments can also be imported as public, just choose Public in access.

But, what if you export a private environment with teams assigned to it? What will happen if you import this environment to a target tenant? Let’s answer that in the next scenarios.

  • Import a private environment with Team existing in both Source and Target tenants
  • Import a private environment with Team existing from Source but not existing in Target tenant

Import a private environment with Team existing in both Source and Target tenants

  1. In the Content Management, choose the content that you want to import
  2. Choose Import button
  3. In the Import Environment, maintain the following:
    1. Environment ID
    2. Environment Version
    3. Activate: Yes/No
    4. In the Access, automatically this will be set as Private
    5. Assign or Unassign the Authorized Teams
  4. Then choose Import as New

Note: In the Authorized Teams, admin will have an option to either retain, change, or add more teams.

Import a private environment with Team existing from Source but not existing in Target tenant

  1. In the Content Management, choose the content that you want to import
  2. Choose Import button
  3. Create Missing Teams: Yes/No
  4. In the Import Environment, maintain the following:
    1. Environment ID
    2. Environment Version
    3. Activate: Yes/No
    4. In the Access, automatically this will be set as Private
    5. Assign or Unassign the Authorized Teams
  5. Then choose Import as New

Note: The system will either create the missing teams if the teams that are currently assigned in the environment that will be imported are present in the target tenant. The administrator must then assign the users in the created team as users are not importable due to different team composition is different tenants. Or, totally not include the team in the import if Create Missing Teams = No.

Now, if you have gone through or already read the blogpost, SAP PaPM Cloud SM: Introducing the Environment Access Management Screen you should already know the conditions and expected result when an environment is created or imported as private which is explained in two (2) different scenarios with Privileged Role Access and Authorized Team Membership Granting Access.

That’s it! I hope the examples provided in this blogpost are able to show you the things that you need to know about the extended Environment Access Level Functionality. Now the only thing left is for you to explore. Till the next new features from SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model. Enjoy!

entry.title: SAP PaPM Cloud Standard Model: What’s New as of 2025-09-01?
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community members!

We’re excited to share the latest updates in SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud (SAP PaPM Cloud) Standard Model. This release introduces new roles, enhanced data management capabilities, and flexible feature toggling to improve your modeling and administrative experience.

 

I. Modeling Screen

We are introducing a new role in the SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud – Standard Model for the modeling screen called MODELING_RUN. Similarly with MODELING_READ role, the users with MODELING_RUN will not be able to perform changes in the Modeling screen, but users with this role can activate and run functions and execution activity in the process template level in the Modeling.
